title: Prohibition on Use by the United States Government of Commercial Spyware That Poses Risks to National Security

enrichment.summary: This executive order prohibits U.S. government agencies from using commercial spyware that poses significant security or intelligence risks or could be misused by foreign governments. It establishes procedures for assessing, reporting, and coordinating the use and procurement of such spyware to protect national security while ensuring respect for human rights and democratic values.
potential_concerns: The prohibition on commercial spyware use poses operational challenges for intelligence-community-personnel and federal law enforcement officers needing advanced surveillance tools to counter threats, potentially limiting their capabilities (themes: intelligence-operations, cybersecurity-national-security).

Restrictions on spyware procurement may slow rapid response efforts or intelligence sharing, creating interagency coordination difficulties, especially for agencies dependent on real-time data collection (theme: interagency-coordination).

While the order protects u-s-citizens and journalists-media-professionals from foreign surveillance abuses, it may inadvertently limit the governmentâ€™s ability to investigate legitimate threats without complex waiver processes or delays (themes: human-rights-international, cybersecurity-national-security).

Foreign governments and officials adversely impacted by this order may resort to developing or acquiring alternative spyware, potentially escalating cyber countermeasures and undermining international cooperative norms (themes: cybersecurity-national-security, human-rights-international).
